body: @cheddar : I added a "versioning" system to the URISegmentPullers so that they try to grab the latest versions. Also the docs have been updated to reflect the change. It requires a new druid-api cut though. Please check it out and see if it is going in the right direction.

Hi again, 

Yesterday, I tried to check this patch on my production cluster and it didn't work. Today, I have decided change the dataset, use more real and bigger dataset, and the error reproduces again.

I attached on this gist: https://gist.github.com/andresgomez92/c509e7a6e34b13f2d06d , the new dataset, and the modified classes with the new interval to index and query, and a one more test.

Regards,
Andres
also would be great to have an endpoint somewhere that we can see all recent rule changes across all datasources - not sure where that would live, though...

:-1:  Production setups will be 1.8 and linux either now or in the near future. Performance improvements are significant with fastest vs fastestJava.

Would be worth keeping track of as things go on though.
given the benchmarks, i'm more inclined to keep the original behavior

Hrm, those can be pretty compelling numbers.  In general, I fear native bindings because they can introduce interesting, unexpected problems.  When they speed things up, it can definitely be useful, however.

Given that the library tries to do local resolution of compiled things (similar to what we did with sigar), I think it's an ok tradeoff to keep it around.  That said, sigar was moved to an extension entirely because it is native code and has caused core dumps before (it's 100% not thread-safe).  I'd feel more comfortable if this was an extension point, but am willing to compromise.

Given that this slows down performance on Mac laptops and that most people are going to come and kick the tires on whatever their developer box is, it might make sense to actually be more intelligent about which should be used based on the environment.  It seems like the library does a poor job determining what the "fastest instance" is on a Mac, so perhaps we should add logic that defaults to non-native when it sees that it is running on a Mac?

While you're in the documentation, maybe you'd like to address a couple of trivial things in Tutorial:A-First-Look-at_Druid.html (seemed too trivial to have a separate jira, especially as you might want to just leave them alone):
. The tarball to be downloaded is druid-0.7.1-rc1-bin.tar.gz, but the command for extracting the 
  content uses the file druid-0.7.1-bin.tar.gz.  Perhaps it would be best not to use the version 
  in the file name at all, for when the version next gets updated.
. run_example-server.sh:  When I ran this, the "wikipedia" example was "1"   instead of "2". 
  Perhaps just say 'Select the "wikipedia" example'.
. You are assuming java is present - a very reasonable assumption, but I happened to try this stuff out 
  on a VM where java didn't exist until I installed it.

In Tutorial:-Loading-Streaming-Data.html in this sentence:
  We will be working with the same Wikipedia edits data schema from out previous tutorials.
"out" should be "our".

(This has to be one of the most common uncaught typographical errors.)
Does it affect ingestion/indexing performance at all?

@cheddar : Added significant updates and optimizations.

Now the Extraction functions can be either a RENAME or a REBUCKET and have optimizations for group-by and topN depending on if it is a 1:1 rename or a one-many rebucket.

I haven't run any detailed statistic on indexing. For the benchmark index, it took 13 minutes and 35 seconds without compression, and 14 minutes and 23 seconds with compression for a 525MB segment. That's nowhere near scientific however, since I don't know what else may have been running on the machine at the same time, or if my laptop was plugged in for both indexing times.

I wouldn't go as far as saying the library is doing a poor job, since the definition of "fast" is very much application-specific. For most applications, I would imagine that the time it takes to decompress or uncompress the data matters more than the overhead of the native bindings. In our case we just happen to make a lot of calls and the binding overhead may be what is slowing us down here.

Given that people's preference is to stick with what works best in production, I am going to close this. We can revisit if we ever have evidence of when this may not the best choice in production. If someone feels strongly about making this configurable, please submit a pull request, but I doubt this is going to make or break someone's decision whether to use Druid or not.
have added tests from #1211 and updated the PR with fixes for handling more null value cases.

there were some more boundary cases missing, have updated PR with fixes for handling those. 
things should be good now.

Apparently you need to add unit tests for this so the coverage doesn't drop > 1%.

maybe we should also add a constraint on the configuration parameter to make sure this is within expected range?

I think the reason for having the check was given by @gianm in this commit https://github.com/druid-io/druid/commit/6e33cd4e0adc340e352f80636d34bdc89054825a. Maybe he can chime in to make sure this won't break his intended change.

I feel this is a little more than just a last minute fix, so I'm proposing we leave this to be fixed in 0.7.2
@xvrl i will

That change fixed a bug in which the coordinator would drop all segments if it started running cleanup before it finished polling the metadata storage for available segments for the first time. That happened once in our cluster and it wasn't fun :)

There may have been a similar bug for coordinators that lose leadership, since when that happens their availableSegments are cleared out, but their stuff-doer threads keep running for a bit (until they realize they're supposed to stop). The change in 6e33cd4 would have fixed that too, if it existed.
So :-1: unless there is another strategy in place for preventing the coordinator from doing whacky things when availableSegments is empty due to recently having gained or lost leadership.
Hi @haadcode what version are you using?
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1205
Just saw that there's 0.7.1.1 released. I updated the cluster to use the latest and I don't get the exception anymore. Seems like it's fixed. Sorry for extra work!

I've added some JMH microbenchmarks to the compression benchmarks, which show that compression is not any slower, and in most cases slightly faster, leading me to believe that the differences in query times are likely due to garbage collection times, where compression may add a small overhead.

Based on that, I am suggesting that we make compression the default.
@xvrl I think we should update a reasonably sized cluster and see what happens

I'm happy to test this on one of our clusters as long as everyone is on-board with this PR getting merged, and the only remaining change to be made is whether or not to turn it on by default by changing the following constant: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/5b1a534cac2204e8ac9e01cee0691780ad2f2728/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexSpec.java#L45
@rasahner @gianm fixed according to your comments. Any more thoughts?

It would be good to fix the "out" typo in Loading-Streaming-Data.html.  I have been through all of the files - I will read them all again later this evening or tomorrow.

I agree with what it says at the bottom of that file, that getting data into druid can be difficult for first-time users (of which I am still one).  Right now I don't have any good suggestions for helping with that.  I hope that in the next couple of months I'll be getting something going with both the pull- and push-based streamingmodels, and I hope that I'll be able to say something useful - but I don't think that will involve organizational changes.

Hi @jitesh4112 : Please see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md on styling. There seems to be significant deviance from the standard styling. If you are using IntelliJ you can use the style at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/raw/master/intellij_formatting.jar

If my research is correct, Azure does not have a unique URI scheme. This would make this PR the first deep storage impl that is not identifiable by URI alone, but _requires_ either non-standard identification wrapping (segment spec) or host capability negotiations. Is there ANYONE out there who uses some sort of URI prefix (as per cassandra using `cassandra://`) to indicate the special handlers needed for Azure connections?

Hi @drcrallen,

I don't think Azure provides specific URI prefix on its API.

There is a section on this [link](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dd135715.aspx), "Resource URI syntax", that describes the URI syntax for storage resources.

Note that the lack of support for Azure-specific URI is not a blocker per-se, but it does limit the capacity to implement `io.druid.segment.loading.URIDataPuller` and any future capacities that handle URIs in a smarter manner.

If a `io.druid.segment.loading.URIDataPuller` (and potentially pusher/archiver/whatever in the future) which handles general `https` targets would handle Azure correctly then it should not be an issue. Even if `https` would work but `azure` or some other scheme is more "optimized" that should be ok. But if functionality requires `com.microsoft.azure` packages even over `https`, then this could cause conflicts down the road.

Overall I'm feeling good about this PR, but would like to see the classes changed to not have an instanced Compression Utils if possible. I would still like to have a second look at the PR before it is ready to merge.
Give me some time to improve the code and unit tests based on your feedbacks :smile:

@xvrl Since there is some uncertainty about the behavior of the compiler vs what is really being used currently, and if it modifies byte code at all, I have modified the PR to have a separate POM which contains the error checking stuff. You can now compile it with the command
`mvn -f errorprone-pom.xml clean compile test-compile`
@drcrallen do you think it would possible to make it a maven profile? this way we could also add other things such as findbugs or other tools that we may not want to run all the time pretty easily.

@xvrl  Yep, that works:
`mvn clean compile test-compile -Dcompiler=errorprone`
@fjy would you mind also submitting a corresponding PR to https://github.com/metamx/server-metrics, to make SysMonitor and JvmMonitor schemaless as well?
As a note, the profile is called `strict`, so you can simply say `mvn clean compile test-compile -P strict`

@nishantmonu51 What if you could start up the node as a replica of _multiple_ other nodes?  It could download the whole set of segments and then when the node actually shows up, the coordinator can make sure that things make sense?

That is, you bring up your hs1.8xl's set to replicate like 9 2TB nodes (for example).  That initialization happens as fast as possible during the "init" phase.  Then they join and the coordinator does its stuff?

I'm not overly familiar with RabitMQ's pika internals, but if you turn on any of the [mandatory delivery](http://pika.readthedocs.org/en/latest/examples/blocking_publish_mandatory.html) or [delivery confirmation](http://pika.readthedocs.org/en/latest/examples/blocking_delivery_confirmations.html) stuff does it still exhibit this behavior?

@drcrallen and @fjy.
Reproducing the BUG is fairly easy you can try deleting all the segments and you will see that some of them won't be gone.
Understanding why this happens it is straightforward from the code in this PR.
I do understand that we can not merge this since it will cause another problem, i am fine with that, we have a work around the leak bug.
Now the question is: Should i close this PR and submit an issue or how should i proceed ?
Finally i will be more than happy to discuss a general fix for both problems

@b-slim : You should probably submit an issue regardless of the solution approach since it is technically an issue. If you are able to publicly disclose any workaround that would be preferable as well. Also please link to Gian's comment above in the issue so that it is clear any solution must account for that scenario. This PR should be fine to keep the solution in because it keeps the discussion history, but as long as the issue has a link here it is not at all required and at your discretion. If it is not ready for review yet, please either change the title to indicate as such (something like `Fix bug: Ensure that the last segement will be delete (DO NOT MERGE YET)`) _or_ just closing this PR and re-opening when you're ready for review. Note that github doesn't like to re-open pull requests when the commit history has changed on the PR, so don't rebase until the PR is open unless you're trying to just close and forget this PR (which is fine)

_TL;DR_
File Issue: yes.
New PR or this one: your choice.
